topic.title: [Forum] Welcome to Programming.Net!
topic.body:
**Programming.Net** is a programming forum hosted here on the #ZeroNet. We want to help you with all your programming-related questions and if you have any cool projects that you are working on then please feel free to post them here.
-
##Rules

But before you begin entering our forum and beginning to post please look at the rules below:

1. If you are asking a question then please include the identifier `[Question]` in your thread's title.
2. If you are posting a program of yours then please include the identifier `[My Program]` in your therad's title.
3. If you are posting something programming-related (of which is **not NSFW**) then include the identifier `[Other]` in your thread's title.
4. If you are posting a resource for learning to program then use the identifier `[Learning]` in your thread's title.
5. If you are posting a resource (such as libraries, fonts or graphics) for programming projects then please use the identifier `[Resource]` in your thread's title.
6. No posting of anything related to **drugs**, **pornography** and **anything else inmoral**. Only moral people with a life are allowed to post on this forum.
7. No hate speech, such as **offending peoples' religious beliefs** for example.
8. No off-topic posts.

-
##Suggestions
If you have any further suggestions then please leave them in the comments section below. Thanks everyone for reading this and following the community rules.

topic.title: [Other] Anybody heard of Nimrod (Programming language)?
topic.body:
A while ago I stumbled upon a programming language called Nim (previously called Nimrod). And upon looking at the tutorial documentation I must say it is a great language (something to entertain me whilst I do Python, because pure-oop approachs are confusing at points). It has type inference if you wish to use such a feature but variables can also be statically typed (as I you can tell it what type a vareiable identifier must be).
-
On the Nim site is states that the compiler (as it is a compiled language) can even compile to C++ or Objective C. What does this mean? Well, that it can compile to an extremely fast prpogramming language, **C++**.
-
Anyway here are some links:

1. [Official Nim Hoempage](http://nim-lang.org/)
2. [Nim on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nim_%28programming_language%29)
-
I don't know about you guys but I am definately going to be learning Nim (I started yesterday (I forgot all the stuff I learnt when first looking at Nim when I first stumbled upon it)) as a dedicated language to my _portfolio-of-programming-languages_ because hoesntly it is a great programming language.

topic.title: [Learning] Learn to script in Bash
topic.body:
I have stated a little site dedicated to learning to program/script in Bash. I have kicked-off the tutorial series with the notorious programming tutorial; the `Hello World` tutorial.
-
##Don't know what Bash is?
-
**Bash** or **B**ourne **A**gain **SH**ell is a scripting language commonoly used for writing small programs that maintain systems and such like servers. Although, if used by a creative person, you can write really cool little programs with it.
-
You can get it here at this ZeroNet address: 17wS1n8SJjkJ9uBg834m3NNiWkqdP29aWM .

topic.title: [My program] libtype - Easy library for getting the data type of values
topic.body:
So you are writing you Python program and have `int`s `str`s and all the others everwhere but you need a simple way to check if it is a matching `type of...` of just need an easy way to get the type of the value. This is where `libtype` comes in its has function that return boolean values like `isInt(value="d")` and also functions that return a string containing the name of the data type `getType(value=3)`.
-
##And the source code?
-
I am currently working on the library. It will be available very soon (tomorrow). Probably at [https://notabug.org/deavmi/libtype](https://notabug.org/deavmi/libtype). I will post a new thread onto the forum as soon as it has been completed and the source code has been uploaded to [Notabug](https://notabug.org).

topic.title: Python os and os.path
topic.body: If I am correct the `os` module in Python is well a module, does that mean that os.path is a class named `path` in the `os` module which holds a function named `exists`?

1_1JdoX9KdJeRVjN9zvK8N9C5jybEHzZe8n.body:
> [tuttle](#comment_1_15UMhD3kLoLC4xbcf9J5HKDfwk47vnBA6T): Hi,I really like BitTorrent Sync but it is not free. Have you ever tried it? Something similar would be cool.Perhaps ZeroNet could be used to share folders accompanied with a simple web admin interface. What do you think?

Yes, you could try [Syncthing](https://syncthing.net). It is open-source, sadly they changed from the GPL to the MPL. Syncthing is awesome, like really awesome. Syncthing has a beautiful (Twitter Bootstrapped) web interface for controlling.

4_1JdoX9KdJeRVjN9zvK8N9C5jybEHzZe8n.body:
Just added the following functions to `libtype`:

* `isInt()` which checks whether an object is of the type `int` (meaning it was derived from the `int` class).
* `isBool()` which checks whether an object is of the type `bool` (meaning it was derived from the `bool` class).
* `isStr()` which checks whether an object is of the type `str` (meaning it was derived from the `str` class).
* `isFloat()` which checks whether an object is of the type `float` (meaning it was derived from the `float` class).
* `isComplex()` which checks whether an object is of the type `complex` (meaning it was derived from the `complex` class).

More to come soon.
